column1: Before 5 August 2022, will a NATO member state accuse Russia of using a chemical or biological weapon in Ukraine?
column6: ['Technology', 'Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
For passage ofvtime
Passage of time
Too late for an investigation to each such a conclusion now
Updating for passage of time.
I'll take my chances with 6 days to go :)
If they did it would be the excuse the members of nato would use to increase the supply of long range missiles to target chemical warfare storage facilities
Time is running out
calibrating
Russia has begun to succeed with conventional weaponry, no need to shock the world using Chem or Bio weapons.
As Russian military consolidates gains an escalation to cause panic and fear so they can make the shorter drive to Kyiv is far from unthinkable.
Updating per passage of time and decreasing resolution period

Adjusting for passage of time. Accusations remain likely, but may be delayed until active combat ends for NATO to take the action described. Regrettably, as of this writing, an end to the hostilities appears unlikely before the 5 August deadline.

Thankfully, it seems that—after all that’s happened so far—this question hasn’t already resolved as ‘Yes’. Given the dwindling timeframe, now assessing slightly less than 0.5% chance of this happening in our timeframe.
No evidence of this, although shelling of industrial areas where chemicals are stored can cause secondary exposure if industrial chemicals are released.

Adjusting my forecast down but remaining quite apart from consensus view. Russia advancing slowly in the East (Donbas) but stalled in the South (Kherson). The more frustrated Putin is, the more likely he is to order the use of chemical or biological weapons. I think the current consensus is optimistic and underestimates the malice and wickedness of the Putin regime, hence my forecast shows quite a divergence from the consensus view.

The war is grinding down to a conflict with extensive use of conventional weapons. It is also unlikely that there will be a situation in which use of chemical or nuclear weapons would tip the balance of power.

They are reckless enough to use them, but have made some progress recently so the need might not be there. Deadline is relatively soon, plus if such an attack were to take place Russia might use it in a opaque way meaning NATO states may wait for more evidence before making an accusation.

Difference from the alleged use of chemical weapons in Syria - probably - is that there is a significant number of Russian ground troops in Ukraine. Therefore, using chemical or biological weapons may be against Russia's best interests.
Russian strategy making progress = decreased likelihood of any chemical/biological escalation
NATO-Turkey=0%

As the war goes on and we have a clearer picture on what's happening, it just doesn't seem like Russia needs to use these weapons to achieve battlefield gains. If you look up the effectiveness of chemical and biological weapons on the battlefield, they surprisingly aren't that effective anyway.
Feels unlikely to occur given not already done so by now.
Passage of time.
Decreasing for passage of time. Does anyone think the Russian reaction to US HIMARS delivery last week makes escalation meaningfully more likely?

It seems that international pressure against the use of chemical weapons continues to influence Russian military decisions. Attacks on Ukrainian chemical manufacturing plants [1] is essentially conducting such an attack, under a new hybrid warfare paradigm. However, after the attack on the nitric acid chemical plant 4 days ago, no NATO member referred to the incident as a chemical attack, though it would have been a good opportunity to do so. With this in mind, it seems that Russia may actually have to use chemical munitions to warrant such an accusation.
Even if Russia DOES, how much to discount that probability by NATO decided not to risk escalation with a formally lodged complaint?
60ish days left

MFA Russia: “According to information received from captured Ukrainian servicemen, nationalist militants are preparing another #provocation with the use of toxic substances in Sumy. Foreign journalists are already in Sumy to film.”
Passage of time plus several weeks of the “new phase” in the east without even major rumors of chemical/bio
Reducing because Putin did not declare full mobilization in May which suggests that Russia is unwilling for now use all resources available to them.
Really just not a lot of time left in the question period

Passage of time. I’m starting to think that if Russia was going to use these terrible weapons (and be caught), it would’ve happened by now. Russia’s military defeats continue to pile up, and its territorial gains are being reversed, but no sign of WMD war crimes on top of the “conventionally” executed war crimes. Fingers crossed.
Time
In my mind, this is the blackest of black swan events.

Change in rhethoric from the Russians: increasingly war skeptical reporting even in state media, perhaps to create narrative room for deescalation.Additional tensions due to the application of Sweden and Finland to NATO: NATO is probably not going to escalate issues with Russia. None of the blocks seems escalating beyond the current war, as such I find it slightly less likely for Russia to use any chemical or biological weapon and for NATO to fabricate this sort of claim.
Published May 15, 2022 via the Atlantic Council - https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/ukrainealert/will-putin-use-chemical-weapons-in-ukraine/
Passage of time.

It's in the US's vested interest to take action once chemical weapons are confirmed. But it hasn't been confirmed yet and the US hasn't taken action. I'm sure if there were such a use most times the US would have some sort of intel to confirm this with a likely probability. Furthermore, because Russia did not declare war on Ukraine on its May 9 parade holiday thingy majig nor seems to be making major plans for a surge of forces to continue the assault, coupled with reports that Putin is planning for an extended period of war, it tells me he is going to remain constrained. Russia launched the assault knowing Ukraine wasn't NATO territory but they are well aware that if chemical or nuclear weapons are used, this will bring them into direct involvement with the US, its top adversary.

I think the chance of a false flag attack on this is low. Tensions are already high enough. I certainly don't see Russia doing this in reality. This is a fight about global superiority and perceptions play a big part of this. Russia and even the other BRICS Nations believe that Russia has good cause to do what it is doing. This is Russia's version of the Cuban missile crisis. Using chemical weapons would reduce their credibility.
Lowering after no mobilization, hard to see a good strategic reason for Russia to do this
After today's speech and also considering his apologies to Israel PM for the words of Lavrov, I think Putin is realizing that he was biting off more than he could chew.
I’m scaling back probability, as Putin’s War may actually be scaling back by then.

Updating forecast - recent comments made by the Russian foreign ministry indicated that nuclear weapons are off the table. An emergent redline seems to be forming between NATO and Russia, and Russia seems to be signaling that they understand this. There would be no reason for Russia to outwardly state this via their FM otherwise.
Following the crowd.

A new assessment indicates that Russian forces are likely *considering* the use of chemical weapons to achieve battlefield advantages in the battle for Donbas. No accusations by a NATO member state has been made. There is difficulty in, due to incomplete information, objectively or subjectively evaluating the likelihood of such an outcome. If decision-making has moved beyond the stage of tactical consideration, it is still not clear whether the negative expected utility associated with such an action, given that risk acceptance is bounded in a random walk, limits the magnitude of these risks. EU( . ) = [-1, 1]. In the limit, behavioral costs are constrained by decision-making under conditions of uncertainty given known risks and utilities. Since the IFP only requires a credible accusation, it is increasingly likely that signaling will be made by Ukrainian IC. Involvement by a NATO member state, given a credible report, will require that the conflict escalate regionally. Imperfect information, reputational costs and uncertainty continue to mitigate against such accusations, however credible.
Azovstal would've been a prime target for a tactical chemical weapon. Note:

I think it's a near certainty these weapons have been used. I think it's likely proof will find its way into one or more member states, and I think given having proof that proof will be stated publicly
You would think that if they haven’t used them by now they aren’t going to.
Because who knows what lengths there leader will go to to get what he wants when he has the weapons.
Revising up on rumors that Russia will declare a general mobilization around May 9. I think this is unlikely still but they could use a chemical false flag as a justification for escalation.

I think it is likely (80%+ with high confidence) that chemical weapons have or will be used in Ukraine. This increases if Russian conventional military approaches seem to be less effective. May well be instrumental in fall of Kiev. I have deducted 10% because I am unsure if NATO member will call Russia out on such or if they will leave it to international courts etc.
We want P(A) P(A| B)

Russian command and control at this point is pitiful, and probably worse with chemical weapons than (hopefully) with nuclear weapons. Moreover, as more seasoned veterans begin to be killed, including generals, and Putin replaces them with "true believers", the chances of a chemical weapon being used is increasing slightly on a daily basis. However, Putin, for all his brutality, seems to be careful not to entangle NATO (for example, there have been no attacks on cities during NATO leader visits). Moreover, Putin has refrained from attacking NATO supply vehicles.
Chances seem to be receding: if they weren’t used in Mariupol then I doubt they will be used at all.
Moving down a little. I know he used them in Syria but the Ukraine is a totally different situation with much higher stakes.
Raising my prediction until after May 9. Based on the discussion of the steel plant here:

Putin is more likely to be able to persuade his surviving generals to do something like this than to start flinging nukes about. Chemicals are more likely than biologicals, I think; they can be more closely targeted, so there's less chance of accidentally wiping out more of his diminishing forces. This assumes a level of competence in the Russian military for which there has been scant recent evidence, though.
I think it will definitely happen because there is evidently of Russia’s weapons being highly dangerous.

Those who use flechettes [ https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2022/04/24/what-are-flechettes-a-brutal-weapon-used-in-ukraine ] are likely not opposed to use other ammo that routinely causes high numbers of "collateral" among "soft targets".
Bullies and murders do not carry weapons into a fight which they are not prepared to use. Putin’s leadership is based on murder and fear.

Back to my original 10% as I think the Mariupol claim was clearly a false alarm and should not change my assessment of how likely this is. I'll start decreasing slowly for the passage of time in a week or so.
After two false alarms it would seem that they would have used them in Mariupol if they were going to use them.
Putin's order of waiving the storming of the Mariupol Azovstal site.
I think associated with such an accusation, is the increased risk of war between NATO and Russia. Even if there were be plausible evidence NATO will behave reluctantly.
Very likely given Russia's record in Syria.
The narrative from the administration is falling apart and seems to have been abandoned by NATO IMHO

This link gives an indication of the burden of proof that might be required and a mention of the time it might take a for a substantiated report. : https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/ukraine-chemical-weapons-1.6420933

Continuing to creep down as time passes from the Mariupol allegations. I am creeping slowly as we are still waiting to see if/how the war changes character as the focus shifts to the East. I don't see why that shift would make chemical weapons use more likely (if anything, this means Russia fighting among more sympathetic populations), but I have a lot of general uncertainty about how things will change.
Lowering back - seems like Mariupol allegation was a false alarm? Or at least no longer being talked about

Yes, because Russia will use these kind of weapons, not only because they did it before, but in a way they announced that they will do it in Mariupol, when they say „we will smoke out the moles“ referring to the people of Mariupol

That Russia will use chemical weapons? I'd put that in the 0-20% range. That a NATO member will formally accuse Russia of having used chemical weapons? 0% Such an accusation would be yet another prelude to war that NATO members are not willing to make. Maybe Turkey, now that I think about it. Ok, changing it from 0% to 5% because Turkey.
Updating to 38% based on the below considerations.
Lowering based on clarification about white phosphorus.

Given the level of conflict and the fact that Russia is seemingly trying to dehumanize Ukranian population in official state messaging - the accusation of use of chemical weapons seems likely. There is also desire from Russian government to show some results by May 9th anniversary of victory over Germany which may result in use of chemical/biological weapons as a way to hasten the end of conflict.
- US and UK are investigating reports (from Ukraine militar) of chemical weapons being used by Russia in the Ukraine war

White phosphorous or a riot control agent mentioned by US officials yesterday, along with hedging about how hard it is to verify these accusations. Seems like the Mariupol attack is unlikely to be subject to a NATO accusation so reducing again a bit toward my original probability.
“ Ukraine's chief of intelligence warns that Russia may be preparing terrorist attacks on Russian soil” which can only be (if true) for escalatory purposes.

White phosphorous not counting brings me back to my original probability, plus about 5% due to the increased uncertainty regarding Russia's potential to escalate. I agree with the GJOpen's decision to not count white phosphorous. White phosphorous has been used in many conflicts, including most recently in 2020 in Nagorno-Karabakh, and including by the United States in WW2, Vietnam, Iraq and Afghanistan. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_phosphorus_munitions
This question is pretty cheeky to change the terms halfway through. It should be deleted, the brier score disregarded and then reissued with clearer wording.

Western officials seem to be mostly "urging caution" and managing expectations of how long it would take to verify this claim. So, I'm still up a lot from where I was yesterday now that there has been an actual public accusation from someone. But I'll keep revising down if credible experts and people with power in NATO keep voicing caution about this specific accusation. I think the underlying probability of use in war and incentive to use chem weapons in this war are still pretty low.

Some muttering about chems in Mariupol; standing by for actual news instead of rumours. Vlad the Shirtless seems increasingly desperate, erratic and distant from reality, so I'm bumping up a bit just in case.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/apr/12/did-russia-really-use-chemical-weapons-mariupol-ukraine-expert-remain-sceptical
edit: slider slipped

Most recent statement from Zelenskyy that Russia *could* use chemical weapons. He also noted that this matter has been discussed with his allies. Note the unconfirmed reports regarding *has been used*. Zelenskyy sources a pro-Russian militia. No NATO member state is involved in *any* accusation, implied or otherwise. Accusation by a NATO member would be made based on credible information and would require escalation militarily. Non-credible accusations involve reputational costs, increasing the risk involved in the bargaining calculus among allies. This matter would involve a coordination problem in order to not escalate further interstate involvement. This would require an accusation or definitive statement by Ukraine to resolve the coordination problem.
Bumping on Mariupol allegations
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-braces-new-russian-offensive-moscow-dismisses-rape-allegations-2022-04-12/
Perhaps phosphorus munitions rather than chemical: https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/ukraine-says-checking-unverified-information-that-russia-used-chemical-weapons-in-mariupol
Reports on social media now seem to indicate it's less clear than it seemed yesterday.

Russia has probably poured sarin or some similar chemical agent on the brave Ukrainian battalion in Azovstal in Mariupol. The Western mainstream reaction: Can it be verified? No, because the Russians block all access to Mariupol. That should be sufficient verification. The Q is about the accusation, not the actual fact. Russia will probably do it anyway and deny it immediately after.
Zelensky is holding back from accusing Russia just yet: https://twitter.com/SamRamani2/status/1513639055992442882
https://www.cnbc.com/2022/04/11/pentagon-monitoring-reports-of-possible-russian-chemical-weapons-attack-in-mariupol.html

The Azov Battalion already accused Russia of using chemical weapons in Mariupol (https://kyivindependent.com/national/azov-says-russia-used-chemical-weapons-in-besieged-mariupol/) - and apparently the USA and NATO are investigating the issue (https://globalnews.ca/news/8752429/ukraine-russia-chemical-weapon-attack-mariupol/).
Looks like the UK is on the verge of accusing

Why Russia would use chemical weapons in Mauripol after NATO warned that Chemical Weapon use would bring us into the conflict on the ground? Azov units are known to quarter underground and the tactic for flushing them out is to flood the tunnels not gas them. But here are - about to go hot in WWIII. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fos0rxeQi9E
Following the crowd.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_the_Syrian_civil_war https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Military_District https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Dvornikov#Russo-Ukrainian_War
https://twitter.com/DefenceHQ/status/1513386967165251584
Will Russia use these weapons, or will there be an accusation?
The Pescov remarks on nuclear weapons and the Russian "tragedy". Crocodile tears?

As Russia continues to fail at its objectives it will be more likely to consider more drastic measures to achieve them. However, I think Russian leadership also recognizes that using chemical or biological weapons could potentially bring in NATO, which would result in the total defeat of Russian forces and/or lead to an escalation to a WMD exchange. Therefore, the risk, while present, is low.
It's a question of strategic psychological warfare. It will escalate as long as the geostrategic goals do not point back to all the backers.

This event is highly unlikely. The costs for such a level of escalation are significantly higher than present costs for the ongoing conflict. The event will most likely, if it occurs, expand the number of states participating in war. This event is likely under conditions that involve significant uncertainty, increasing the risk calculus for Russia and increase levels of destabilization in the international system leading to a likelihood that is extremely low.
Recent warnings of UA use of chemical weapons by RU media would suggest possible Russian deployment of such weapons a la Syria and the ‘warnings’ given prior to those events.
Seems like there is more and more talk of chemical weapons possible. The war is not going well for Russia so their level of desperation is growing. Chemical weapons were used by Russia in Syria.

With atrocities in Kyiv's suburbs uncovered and probably more to be unveiled around Kharkiv and in Mariupol the leap to using chemical weapons is not large in terms of consequences for sanctions and international relations or internal dissent. China is only happy that Russia is pushing the boundaries of what is possible in a war and will not withdraw its support because of such a step. Main concern is whether that is militarily advantageous. And I say it could be a logical step towards Kharkiv from Russia

Recent activity has accusations of other atrocities, maybe it is only a matter of time before Russia will use chem/bio weapons. Russia was working with Syria when they were accused of using chemical weapons. But that is the only recent example I know of. I have been thinking about how I would have scored it prior to the bucha incident and if this would have been enough to change my prediction. I have also been thinking about the planned regrouping around the Donbas region and if that increases or decreases the probability. Some interesting analysis here: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-00948-0
Aleppo redux.
Apparent there are no moral or geopolitical bounds on Russia especially as they have growing China support

Russia has shown its disregard for preexisting radiological dangers in its occupation of Chernobyl, as well as for civilian lives in its recent massacre campaign in Bucha. As such, a chemical or biological attack is not to be ruled out as it seems to be regrouping for a new offensive.
Tough one. Impossible to separate: will Russia use these weapons, will other countries find out about it, will other countries take the step of reporting it.

This one is nearly a coin toss. On the one hand, as sanctions pressure mounts, Russia has more to gain from victory and less to lose. If their impending renewed offensive on the Donbas - which is soon to occur - requires overwhelming preponderance of force to create a breakthrough and even succeed in an encirclement, they may resort to tactical chemical weapons. The reason why the likelihood is relatively lower is that NATO states checking and validating that chemical weapons indeed were used is not easy to do and would require expert validation, something the Russians may preclude altogether.

The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons actually declared that Russia has destroyed its chemical weapons stockpiles in 2017, although the assassination attempts carried out by Russian agents are indicative of a secret chemical weapons program. The fact that Russia has not used chemical weapons so far in Mariupol where they would be tactically useful suggests to me a lack of desire on their part to use these weapons. I think there is a greater probability that a NATO member would make a false accusation based on faulty intelligence, maybe Poland or one of the Baltic states because of the threat Russia poses to their security. Finally I imagine the probability of a chemical or biological attack would be higher as a matter of last resort if the Ukrainians can push the Russians back into the occupied territories. Russian will to use these weapons: 0.02 probability of a false claim:0.05 probability of a last resort attack: 0.25*0.10 = 0.025 0.02 + 0.05 + 0.025 = 0.095 which rounds to 0.10
Updating by guess because of bad math and I don't have time to look at it again.

Updating 65% based on the base rate I've seen stated below for actual use of such weapons (5%) + 1% since I can think of a couple of cases in the news where Russia might consider their use advantageous. (.65x(.05+.01)=.039 rounding up).

With Russia pulling back in Ukraine, likelihood is lower than I’d have given a few weeks ago. But it’s still a possibility that they’d resort to it in desperation if they are unable to secure new (or even existing) territory in Donbas or Crimea.
Use of chemical or biological weapon likely Plan B for Russia
Depends on whether the war with Ukraine is over at the time. In case Russia did not achieve their goals then the number will be higher. And of course if they really use it …
every "surely they won't" situations have been followed by "@#$$$# yes! they did"
Accusations are accusations.

Use of these weapons would further turn the world against Russia and lead to more sanctions from more countries. I do not think it will happen but I also did not think a full invasion of Ukraine would happen so I have to give this some chance.
I hope I'm wrong but I suppose they will.
Russia uses phosphorus weapons so I think this has already happened?
I keep it low for now. My reasoning is like @JMR2017, If there is an accusation from NATO, then NATO has to intervene, and then things will get even more complicated.

While I do not doubt that Putin is capable of ordering this action, the supply issues appear to be an issue, and if this type of weapon were readily available, they would have been used at this point.

My initial thought is that chemicals weapons have a limited amount of effectiveness in the battlefield compared with just using conventional weapons: https://www.politico.eu/article/why-the-world-banned-chemical-weapons/ Likely similar with biological weapons. Therefore my preliminary odds are 5%.
They won’t move things militarily and will only encourage even more severe sanctions, so I would think this is pretty unlikely.
Key point is NATO has to accuse. That then requires a response from NATO. Add that individuals and small groups in non combat situations (whatever that means) don't count, I forecast low for now.

Base rate: 5% (use of chemical/biological weapons in international conflicts is very rare) Scenarios: - Putin intentionally uses these weapons on a big scale to subdue Ukraine: 3% (seems like mass killing isn't his intention, would make long-term occupation much harder, NATO blowback would be severe, risk of domestic issues) - Putin intentionally uses it on a small scale: 5% (shifting momentum and Ukrainian counterattacks might change his mind) - Russian army accidentally uses it on a small scale: 2% (they've had a fair amount of blunders but this would put their lives at risk) - NATO member falsely accuses Russia: 5% (would normally be higher but such an accusation would put more pressure on NATO to intervene which is the opposite of what they want)
I do not see Russia doing this, but 5% for chance of false flag incident.

Chemical weapons use is rare across all conflict conflict. Syria's civil war ran for ~10 years with a handful of chemical weapons uses. Likewise for Iraq's decades-long campaigns against internal dissidents. I think the only "recent" use of chemical weapons in a major conventional, interstate conflict was the Iran-Iraq war in which Iraq used them against an otherwise likely superior foe. Given that there have been dozens of inter-state conventional conflicts in that period with no other uses, I think the base rate of actual, intentional use is maybe 5% and would guess that the current case is about typical. However, a mistaken use, mistaken accusation, or spurious accusation is not out of the question either. So, very roughly going with 10%. Would definitely appreciate if anyone else wants to take the time to make the base-rate calculations more precise/otherwise better by looking more carefully at state-state war in recent decades. Also definitely in the market for reasonable inside thinking about why Putin's army may be more/less likely than this average to use chem weapons.
Initial highly subjective forecast.
This one has at least three parts: Did it happen? Did some NATO country know it happened? Will they call it?
